linkTarget.anchoringText: The initial phase of the development started with early production scheme is 1994, after which injection started in the phase 1 development. Phase III, Transition Zone, Infill development and other development projects are currently planned for the future. Transiton zone which is one of the most challenging areas of the reservoir represents, approximately 20% of the estimated reserves. As such the transition zone was characterize and investigated, in order to define the best development strategy for the AB field. Figure 1 shows the different phases of the AB field development.

image-wrap.label: Figure 1
image-wrap.caption: Field AB and Projects In Field Development

formatted-caption.caption-text: Field AB and Projects In Field Development

linkTarget.anchoringText: The entire transition zone of AB reservoir was cored and MDT conducted at various depths, starting from below the free water level FWL at 9070 to the top of the oil leg. Figure 2 shows the MDT data conducted on the well 140 and the results in terms of the percentage of oil recovered from the transition zone at various depths from the free water level.

image-wrap.label: Figure 2
image-wrap.caption: Log of Well 140 Showing Transition Zone

formatted-caption.caption-text: Log of Well 140 Showing Transition Zone

linkTarget.anchoringText: Â

image-wrap.label: Figure 3
image-wrap.caption: Reservoir Model Permeability Distribution

formatted-caption.caption-text: Reservoir Model Permeability Distribution

linkTarget.anchoringText: However, before initiating the dynamic model building, the static model was upscaled and quality checked to ensure validity of the model. In order to quality checking the static model and upscaled model, several properties were compared, including but not limited to permeability and porosity. This is shown in Figure 4 and 5 respectively. Also bulk volumes and grid rotation was investigated to ensure no negative volume and high/negative angles were observed. This is also shown in Figure 5 and 6 respectively.

image-wrap.label: Figure 4
image-wrap.caption: Porosity Distribution In Reservoir Model

formatted-caption.caption-text: Porosity Distribution In Reservoir Model

linkTarget.anchoringText: However, before initiating the dynamic model building, the static model was upscaled and quality checked to ensure validity of the model. In order to quality checking the static model and upscaled model, several properties were compared, including but not limited to permeability and porosity. This is shown in Figure 4 and 5 respectively. Also bulk volumes and grid rotation was investigated to ensure no negative volume and high/ negative angles were observed. This is also shown in Figure 5 and 6 respectively.

image-wrap.label: Figure 5
image-wrap.caption: Bulk Volume Distribution In Reservoir Model

formatted-caption.caption-text: Bulk Volume Distribution In Reservoir Model

linkTarget.anchoringText: However, before initiating the dynamic model building, the static model was upscaled and quality checked to ensure validity of the model. In order to quality checking the static model and upscaled model, several properties were compared, including but not limited to permeability and porosity. This is shown in Figure 4 and 5 respectively. Also bulk volumes and grid rotation was investigated to ensure no negative volume and high/negative angles were observed. This is also shown in Figure 5 and 6 respectively.

image-wrap.label: Figure 6
image-wrap.caption: Reservoir Model Cell Angles

formatted-caption.caption-text: Reservoir Model Cell Angles

linkTarget.anchoringText: AB reservoir acquired 54 fluid samples as part of gathering data and in order to characterize the fluid properties. Thirty six (36) of these fluid samples have been validated for Pressure Volume Temperature (PVT) experiments. Samples collected include both crest and flank locations, in order to characterize the reservoir both aerially and vertically. This is shown in Figure 7.

image-wrap.label: Figure 7
image-wrap.caption: Characterized PVT Fluid Model Property Distribution

formatted-caption.caption-text: Characterized PVT Fluid Model Property Distribution

linkTarget.anchoringText: PVT data was validated before building PVT model used in the reservoir simulation. Validation test includes material balance and Y function. Figure 8 and 9 respectively shows the validations, for the most recently drilled well where MDT PVT sample was acquired i.e. Well 140. After validation of the PVT samples, fluid composition from the validated PVT report was input into the PVT software. In total forty two (42) components were characterized i.e. Methane (C1) to C36+Plus components.

image-wrap.label: Figure 8
image-wrap.caption: Y-Function Quality Check In Well 140

formatted-caption.caption-text: Y-Function Quality Check In Well 140

linkTarget.anchoringText: PVT data was validated before building PVT model used in the reservoir simulation. Validation test includes material balance and Y function. Figure 8 and 9 respectively shows the validations, for the most recently drilled well where MDT PVT sample was acquired i.e. Well 140. After validation of the PVT samples, fluid composition from the validated PVT report was input into the PVT software. In total forty two (42) components were characterized i.e. Methane (C1) to C36+Plus components.

image-wrap.label: Figure 9
image-wrap.caption: Material Balance Quality Check In Well 140

formatted-caption.caption-text: Material Balance Quality Check In Well 140

linkTarget.anchoringText: Components were grouped (lumped) together based on similarities in molecular weight and mole fraction of the individual components. The lumped components composition used in the creating the equation of state (EOS) is shown in Figure 10. The components were combined (lumped) together, in order to reduce the simulation (CPU) time. As the simulation (CPU) time is a function of the number of the equation solved, which is in turn a function of the number of components.

image-wrap.label: Figure 10
image-wrap.caption: Phase Behaviour Before And After Component Lumping

formatted-caption.caption-text: Phase Behaviour Before And After Component Lumping

linkTarget.anchoringText: In tuning the different parameters, a focus was made on the heavier components as these are the parameters with the higher level of uncertainty. Figure 10 shows the variation of Al-Dabbiya zone B fluid composition between the wells. Figure 11 shows the matched achieved after tuning in well 68, which includes conventional and advanced PVT experiments.

image-wrap.label: Figure 11
image-wrap.caption: Experiment Match with EOS

formatted-caption.caption-text: Experiment Match with EOS

linkTarget.anchoringText: Fluid contacts was characterize in reservoir AB using all existing cores, logs and MDT data. Logs, cores and MDT were compared to ensure a match between the saturations. Figure 12 shows the match between logs, MDT and cores used in characterizing the fluid contacts in the reservoir. A gradient of 0.43ft/psi, 0.33ft/psi and 0.1psi/ft were used for the water, oil and gas gradients respectively. Both MDT data, cores and logs were used, in order to quality check each set of interpretation. Well 5 and Well 14 MDT fluid contacts showed very swallow contacts i.e. 8975 and 8905 respectively.

image-wrap.label: Figure 12
image-wrap.caption: Core and MDT Saturation For Contact Characterization

formatted-caption.caption-text: Core and MDT Saturation For Contact Characterization

linkTarget.anchoringText: As such they were excluded as outliners, they did not match with core and log of the respectively wells. Figure 13 shows the variations in fluid contacts seen in the different wells. The dynamic reservoir model uses an average oil water contact (OWC) of 9025ft, a gas oil contact GOC of 8900ft and a free water level of 9070ft.

image-wrap.label: Figure 13
image-wrap.caption: Oil Water Contact Distribution in Field AB

formatted-caption.caption-text: Oil Water Contact Distribution in Field AB

linkTarget.anchoringText: Figure 14 shows the location of Well 18 and Well 49, in respect to the reservoir structure. However, before the petrophysical routine and special core analysis was conducted, an in depth geological and sedimentological analysis was conducted. As a result of this geological and sedimentological analysis 14 lithofacies were defined. These 14 lithofacies was grouped into 3 main lithofacies. These 3 lithofacies were defined as being sufficient to describe the reservoir depositional environment and diagenesis imprint on the reservoir rock as shown in Figure 15.

image-wrap.label: Figure 14
image-wrap.caption: Phase I (Green Polygon) Phase III (Pink Polygon)

formatted-caption.caption-text: Phase I (Green Polygon) Phase III (Pink Polygon)

linkTarget.anchoringText: Figure 14 shows the location of Well 18 and Well 49, in respect to the reservoir structure. However, before the petrophysical routine and special core analysis was conducted, an in depth geological and sedimentological analysis was conducted. As a result of this geological and sedimentological analysis 14 lithofacies were defined. These 14 lithofacies was grouped into 3 main lithofacies. These 3 lithofacies were defined as being sufficient to describe the reservoir depositional environment and diagenesis imprint on the reservoir rock as shown in Figure 15.

image-wrap.label: Figure 15
image-wrap.caption: Geological and Petrophysical Reservoir Characterization

formatted-caption.caption-text: Geological and Petrophysical Reservoir Characterization

linkTarget.anchoringText: Fifty three (53) core plugs were selected from the 3 lithofacies characterize in the sedimentological analysis. Figure 16 shows the relationship between the lithofacies and rock reservoir types. Porosity permeability measurements were made during routine core analysis porous plate and centrifuge measurement method.

image-wrap.label: Figure 16
image-wrap.caption: Reservior Rock Typing Characterization

formatted-caption.caption-text: Reservior Rock Typing Characterization

linkTarget.anchoringText: Both air and mercury measurements were made on the core plugs.? Figure 17 shows the relative permeability measured and simulated in Well 18 and Well 49. From the measured porosity and permeability measurements, log permeability and porosity cross plots created to analyze the relationship between the two parameters in the different wells.

image-wrap.label: Figure 17
image-wrap.caption: Relative Permeability For Well 18 and Well 49

formatted-caption.caption-text: Relative Permeability For Well 18 and Well 49

linkTarget.anchoringText: Figure 18 shows a linear relationship between the two parameters. Also Figures 18 shows that permeability and porosity are higher in DY18 than DY 49, as is to be expected as DY18 is located in the crest of the structure and DY49 is located in the flank of the structure. Hence, lower in has poor reservoir properties.

image-wrap.label: Figure 18
image-wrap.caption: Porosity-Permeability Plots

formatted-caption.caption-text: Porosity-Permeability Plots

poro-perm plot for Thamama Zone BIVL

linkTarget.anchoringText: Figure 19 shows a mixed wet reservoir to water wet reservoir. J Function was created using all the core plugs capillary pressure measurement conducted, representing all the reservoir rock types. Figure 20 shows a very good match between the calculated capillary pressures by the J Function and that of the measured in the laboratory for all the plugs.
